newsitem.title: UK: UK rejects Greenpeace move to halt oil drilling.
newsitem.headline: UK rejects Greenpeace move to halt oil drilling.

text.p: Britain's Department of Trade and Industry (DTI) on Thursday rejected the latest attempt by environmental group Greenpeace to prevent oil exploration in the largely unexplored deep waters of the Atlantic margin north of Scotland.
Earlier, Greenpeace called on the government to suspend its latest batch of offshore oil exploration licences pending the possibility of a European Commission investigation into the licesing round.
But the DTI said the award of oil exploration licences was entirely consistent with EU regulations.
"Greenpeace refer to the environmental impact assessment directive 85 377 EEC," a DTI spokeswoman said.
"There is no requirement under this directive for environmental assessments prior to the granting of licences in the 17th round."
Studies into the potential environmental impact would have to be carried out before permission could be given for development of any hydrocarbon deposits discovered, she said.

In a letter to trade secretary Ian Lang, Greenpeace said it had identified a second way in which the British government had breached environmental protection laws by failing to consider the full impact of drilling on coral reefs in the region.

Greenpeace in March made an official complaint to the European Commission calling for 17th UK round awards to be blocked because environmental assessments required under a 1985 EU directive had not been carried out.
The environmental lobby group also bid for all the acreage on offer in the hope of turning it into a wildlife sanctuary.
The government dismissed the application and awarded 25 operating permits to 14 oil companies.
British Petroleum is leading Atlantic margin oilfield development with its Foinaven project, due on stream soon.
Greenpeace said its ship MV Greenpeace was in the northeast Atlantic and set to sail to the area covered by the 17th licensing round.
